group.name: French
group.systemPrompt: You are an expert app localiser with 10 + years of UI/UX and marketing-copy experience across multiple languages.
group.userPrompt:
For each entry in the CSV snippet below, produce a French-(fr-FR) translation plus two metadata fields: category classification and translation reasoning.

────────────────────────────────────────

RULE 1  Placeholders – preserve EXACTLY
• Curly-brace placeholders       {alphaNumeric}     → regex \{[A-Za-z0-9_]+\}  
• ICU plurals                    {n} …one / …other → keep form intact  
• Hash pattern                   #{number}         → treat “#” as literal text  
• Punctuation after token        {percentile}% , {hour}:{minute}  
• Dart interpolation             $variable         → regex \$[A-Za-z_][A-Za-z0-9_]*  
• Highlighter tags               {highlighter}…{/highlighter} (if ever present)  
Do not change the spelling of any token. Order may change to suit French syntax, but every token must appear exactly once.

RULE 1-bis  French typography
• Insert a (non-breaking) space before « ? », « ! », « : », « ; ».  No additional space before commas or periods.
• Use typographic guillemets « … » for quoted UI copy when relevant.  
• Apply elisions correctly (e.g., *l’introduction*, *d’accès*).  
• Never duplicate punctuation the English source didn’t have.

RULE 2  Tone & style
• Follow the tone grid at the end of this prompt.
• Use tu in friendly buckets, use vous or an impersonal form in System, Legal and Error buckets.  
• Sentence-case for buttons and headers.  
• One “!” allowed in Gamification, Pricing, Social; avoid in Error or Legal.  
• No emojis.  
• Prefer neutral collectives (“la communauté”, “les personnes utilisatrices”) when simple; avoid doublets like “utilisateurs/utilisatrices”.

RULE 3  Length
• If English string is 7–25 chars and French expansion > 60 % (`len_ratio > 1.6`), explain in reasoning.  
• If English string is > 25 chars and French expansion > 25 % (`len_ratio > 1.25`), explain in reasoning.  
• No numeric cap for English strings ≤ 6 chars.

RULE 4  Terminology (glossary)
KEEP / TRANSLATE exactly as flagged.  
• KEEP Stimuler, IELTS, CEFR, Sarah, Premium, PRO, Roadmap, Streak, Paywall, Onboarding (internal labels)  
• TRANSLATE  
  – Trial            → « essai gratuit »  
  – Subscription     → « abonnement »  
  – Upgrade          → « mise à niveau »  
  – Mentor           → « mentor / mentore (selon contexte) ; mentorat (n.m.) »  
  – Callback / Call  → « appel »  
• AI mixed rule – Keep “AI” inside fixed branded phrases (“AI Call”, “AI Tutor”); elsewhere translate to “IA”.  
• Onboarding: translate to « Introduction » when it appears on an end-user screen.

RULE 5  Category Classification
Choose ONE category from this list (use exact spelling):
• Onboarding - welcome messages, initial setup, first-run experience, introductions
• Gamification - achievements, rewards, streaks, progress celebrations, badges
• Progress - performance updates, statistics, learning metrics, feedback
• Conversation - AI tutor dialogue, chat interactions, speaking practice
• Practice - exercise instructions, lesson content, practice activities
• Test-Prep - exam preparation, IELTS content, test-specific material
• Pricing - subscription offers, payment, upgrades, paywall messages
• Notification - alerts, reminders, push notifications, time-sensitive messages
• Error - error messages, warnings, validation feedback, failure states
• Social - sharing features, social accomplishments, community features
• Profile - user profile, library, settings, personal preferences
• System - technical messages, legal text, terms, system status

RULE 6  Translation Reasoning (be thorough yet concise)  
Provide comprehensive explanation covering:  
• Word-choice rationale (key terms, register, connotations)  
• Grammar / tense decisions (why present/past/future, gender/number agreement, tu/vous)  
• Cultural adaptations (what changed for the French audience)  
• Tone adjustments (how you matched the category’s tone requirements)  
• Placeholder handling (whether reordered, kept, or required extra spacing)  
• For modifications: Start with "Modified:" then explain (1) what changed and (2) why the original was inadequate
• If you had to pick between multiple plausible categories, briefly justify your choice.

OUTPUT  
Return CSV rows in this exact order, with no header:  
Key, French Translation, Category, Translation Reasoning

IMPORTANT CSV FORMATTING  
- Use double quotes (") to wrap any field containing commas, quotes, or newlines
- Escape inner double quotes by doubling them ("")
- Every row MUST have exactly 4 fields separated by commas
- Do NOT wrap the entire response in markdown code blocks
- Return ONLY the CSV rows, no additional text 
- Example: purpose.ielts,"Bonjour ! Je suis Sarah et je suis là pour t’aider.",Conversation,"Replaced informal “Hey!” with neutral “Bonjour”; tu-form for friendly AI tone; present tense for immediacy."  
- Example: error.network,"Erreur de connexion réseau",Error,"Added “réseau” for clarity; calm factual tone; no exclamation per Error guidelines."  
- Category must be one word from the list, no quotes
- CRITICAL: Each row MUST start with the exact key from the input entries
- CRITICAL: Return EXACTLY one output row for each input entry—never combine entries
- CRITICAL: If an input entry has multiline English text, still return only ONE output row for that key

TONE GRID – How to write for each category  
• Onboarding & First-run: Warm, welcoming; tu; short sentences.  
• Gamification: Celebratory tone; ≤ 1 “!”; no emojis.  
• Progress / Feedback: Encouraging, data-driven, precise; tu.  
• Conversation / AI Call: Natural spoken language, concise; tu.  
• Practice-Lesson: Clear imperatives; tu; neutral enthusiasm.  
• Test-Prep / IELTS: Formal instructional tone; exam vocabulary; tu.  
• Pricing & Paywall: Persuasive, transparent; ≤ 1 “!”; tu.  
• Notifications & Reminders: Direct; tu; polite urgency.  
• Error & Warning: Calm, solution-oriented; avoids blame; formal vous or impersonal.  
• Social Sharing: Enthusiastic first-person plural; ≤ 1 “!”; tu.  
• Profile / Library: Functional labels; concise; tu.  
• System / Legal: Formal; vous or impersonal; French legal register; no exclamations.
